Posts.Content: Just read your message, hope everything is well with you these days.  I do understand the depression that goes with dealing with this sort of thing that's why they have the support groups.  Please use them if you haven't already.  I hope the Cancer Compass helped you to get some comfort.  My husband went on hiatus at a really inopportune time for me, he just couldn't handle the pressure (imagine how I felt?) So I really understand where you're coming from and can only imagine what I would be feeling if he hadn't snapped out of it.  I'm still leary now because it's hard to trust if he'll be there for future problems if there are any. But I did vent on this site and I felt much better.  If nothing else, you can always use us as a sounding board.
Posts.Title: Male Breast Cancer. 2 years since surgery. Do not have support

Posts.Content: I have been experiencing serious pain in my left elbow and it's swolen to the point that it hurts to straighten completely.  I am on a chemo cocktail of taxotere, cytoxan, and doxorubicen followed by a nuestra shot.  This has been ongoing off and on for about a month.  Has anyone ever experienced this or know of what can be done?   J
Posts.Title: joint pain/swelling

Posts.Content: On Sep 02, 2010 8:24 PM ebonyjwriter wrote: This year, I'll be participating in an incredible event called the Komen Dallas Race for the Cure®.   On October 16, 2010,  I will join thousands of others playing a part in ending breast cancer forever.   Please make a donation to help me reach my personal goal while helping Susan G. Komen for the Cure reach thier goal.   Online donations are simple, and the donation page is secure.   Please go to my fundraising page to make a tax-deductible donation.  Start by searching for my name here:   www.komen-dallas.org "" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.komen-dallas.org " target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.komen-dallas.org /supportme.   If you prefer to write a check, you can mail your donation to me.   Please make your donation payable to Komen Dallas Race for the Cure and write my name in the memo portion.  (Send a private message for mailing instructions) By making a donation on my behalf, you are supporting local breast cancer education, screening, treatment, and outreach along with international research that will someday lead us to a world without breast cancer.     Thanks Make sure you include my birth name (Janice White) when making a donation on my behalf.  Thanks in advance for any support I may get.
Posts.Title: Please Support Me

Posts.Content: It is the kind of port I have and yes it is a nuisance but it doesn't hurt all the time.  Takes some getting used to but after a while the only time you'll notice it is when you're getting dressed.  Now the needle prick was a little painful, more than getting blood drawn, but more like getting a shot.  I didn't get any weird side effects just some initial bruising.  Mine has been in for 7 months.  I have to keep it in until after I finish radiation which means - even though there is no more chemo I still have to go have it flushed once per month.  It's like getting a shot.  Not bad at all.  One friend of mine said after a while she forgot hers was there, well I NEVER forget, but it doesn't hurt.  I can even feel it when I move sometimes but it's more annoying to look at and know it's there than anything.  It took about a month for it to start to fade into the background but it never went away.  You'll be fine.
Posts.Title: Chemo Port

Posts.Content: Hope you haven't had any probs with your port.  I didn't pay attention to the date.  Keep us updated on your treatment, hope all goes well.
Posts.Title: Chemo Port

Posts.Content: Hope you haven't had any probs with your port.  I didn't pay attention to the date.  Keep us updated on your treatment, hope all goes well.
Posts.Title: Chemo Port

Posts.Content: You can always vent and reach out to others for comfort here.  Don't worry so much, it makes it worse.  Just know that whatever happens you can handle it.  I'm going to do some research and see if I can help you.  Stay encouraged.
Posts.Title: do anyone knows

Posts.Content: Good morning.  I was just writing to check on you.  How are you today?  Did you ever get the help you were looking for?  I would like to help if I can.  I live in Dallas  (4 hours away from MD Anderson) and a survivor of stage II bc.  Please don't be discouraged.  We are here for support.
Posts.Title: do anyone knows

Posts.Content: Have you had a biopsy?  Have you checked with your doctors?  About 95% of the time cancer does not hurt, it could be something else.  But in that small 5% when you have cancer and it hurts, it can be very serious and very aggressive.  Please get it taken care of.  If it is breast cancer it can be beaten.  I am certain of it.  This site is very helpful and supportive.  Let me know what you find.  I just found a tumor a month ago.  It was a painful but small lump.  In two weeks it seemed a little larger.  During that time I had gone to the doctor to have it checked and had a biopsy done.  It is malignant and I'm getting ready to start treatments soon (no date yet).  So if it's cancer it can be cured, if it's something else it can be taken care of too.  No need to suffer unnecessarily.  Take care of yourself.
Posts.Title: not sure yet?

Posts.Content: Contacting MD Anderson Cancer Center Main Switchboard (713) 792-2121 Page Operator (713) 792-7090 askMDAnderson  Get answers to your questions about cancer, available treatments, how to become a patient, support groups, insurance information, Houston-area accommodations and much more. 1-877-MDA-6789 (713) 792-3245 (in Houston or outside the U.S.) Language Assistance Translation in Spanish, Portuguese, Arabic, Turkish, Taiwanese, Mandarin, Japanese, Italian, German, French and Vietnamese provided without prior notice. For sign language and other languages, please call 24 hours in advance. Located in the Main Building, floor 1, near The Fountain, room P1.3012. (713) 792-7930, 8:00 a.m.-5:30 p.m. weekdays International Patient Center Representatives can assist foreign patients with paperwork, translation and preparations for their first visit to MD Anderson. (713) 745-0450, 8:00 a.m.-5:00 p.m. weekdays Fax: (713) 745-0456 Jesse Jones Rotary House International Hotel An MD Anderson-operated hotel for patients and family members, conveniently located across the street from Clark Clinic. 1-800-847-5783 In Houston (713) 790-1600 Tours of MD Anderson (713) 792-3363 This is some info to get you started.
Posts.Title: do anyone knows

Posts.Content: Thank you for your testimony.  I really need to hear things like this.  I was diagnosed 3 weeks ago and will begin treatment soon.  But can I ask why you have nerve damage and loss of motion?  I am feeling sharp pains running through my arm muscle where the sentinel node biopsy was done and I'm still pretty tender.  Just need some reassurance and info.
Posts.Title: Update on My "Occult" Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for replying.  I needed to hear this.  I do know a lady in my church that had something similar.  She has limited movement of her left arm because of it but she just lost her husband and I didn't want to bother her with my issues.  I have plenty of prayer partners, so I know I'll get through this.  I was just having a bad day today.  Thanks again, J
Posts.Title: Update on My "Occult" Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: correct, my sister in-law is doing the tomaxofin only thing.  She opted for a radical mastectomy just because she was scared and didn't want to take any chances.  But she's on the meds for 5 years.  This is her fourth year and she's keeping cancer at bay.
Posts.Title: tomaxofin and nothing else???
